event: 1776 - During the American Revolution, the Battle of Valcour Island begins on Lake Champlain. Although a tactical defeat for the Americans under Benedict Arnold, the engagement delays the British advance, contributing to their eventual defeat at Saratoga the following year.
1812 - The Battle of Queenston Heights is fought in the War of 1812. It is the first major land battle of the war and results in a British victory, thwarting an American attempt to invade Canada.
1775 - The Continental Congress authorizes the procurement of two armed vessels, marking the establishment of the United States Navy.
1962 - A U.S. Air Force U-2 spy plane flying over Cuba photographs the construction of Soviet medium-range ballistic missile sites, precipitating the Cuban Missile Crisis.
1965 - The first public burning of a draft card in the United States to protest the Vietnam War takes place. David J. Miller, a Catholic pacifist, burns his card at a rally in New York City.
1964 - The People's Republic of China detonates its first atomic bomb, becoming the fifth nuclear power in the world.
1777 - British General John Burgoyne surrenders his army to American forces at Saratoga, New York, a major turning point in the American Revolutionary War.
1944 - Soviet forces enter Czechoslovakia during World War II, beginning the country's liberation from German occupation.
1781 - British General Lord Cornwallis surrenders to General George Washington at Yorktown, Virginia, effectively ending the American Revolutionary War.
1944 - U.S. forces under General Douglas MacArthur land on the island of Leyte in the Philippines, beginning the campaign to liberate the islands from Japanese occupation.
1797 - The U.S. Navy frigate USS Constitution, famously known as 'Old Ironsides,' is launched in Boston.
1962 - President John F. Kennedy announces a naval 'quarantine' of Cuba in response to the discovery of Soviet missile bases, marking the public beginning of the Cuban Missile Crisis.
1983 - A suicide truck bomber destroys the U.S. Marine barracks in Beirut, Lebanon, killing 241 American servicemen.
1944 - The Battle of Leyte Gulf, the largest naval battle in history, begins in the Philippines. The battle involves hundreds of ships and results in a decisive Allied victory.
1983 - The United States invades the Caribbean island of Grenada in Operation Urgent Fury, following a military coup that overthrew the government.
1942 - The Battle of the Santa Cruz Islands, a major naval engagement between the U.S. and Japan, takes place in the waters of the Solomon Islands during World War II.
1941 - In a Navy Day radio address, President Franklin D. Roosevelt declares that 'America has been attacked' by German U-boats, signaling a shift in the nation's stance on entering World War II.
1962 - The Cuban Missile Crisis ends as Soviet Premier Nikita Khrushchev announces that the USSR will dismantle its missile bases in Cuba in exchange for a U.S. pledge not to invade the island.
1956 - The Suez Crisis begins with Israel's invasion of the Sinai Peninsula, followed by British and French intervention.

1953 - President Dwight D. Eisenhower formally approves National Security Council Paper No. 162/2, which codifies the U.S. policy of containment and reliance on nuclear weapons to deter Soviet aggression.
1968 - President Lyndon B. Johnson announces a complete halt to all air, naval, and artillery bombardment of North Vietnam, effective November 1.
1952 - The United States detonates the first hydrogen bomb, codenamed 'Ivy Mike,' at Enewetak Atoll in the Marshall Islands.
